sense.name: a distinctive behavior, manner or mode of doing something
sense.commentary: STYLE[+quality][+manner][+behavior][+distinctive] Note: can be positive or negative or neutral (unlike Sense 7)
sense.examples: She has an abrasive management style. It's not really Bob's style to brag about his own accomplishments. That style of surfing on small boards was unfamiliar to us. The book describes the harsh style of existence led by the nomadic desert tribes.

sense.name: a distinctive artistic form, as in painting, music
sense.commentary: STYLE[+form][+artistic][+distinctive] Note: refers to characteristic form in some artistic medium
sense.examples: She didn't care for the flowery literary style of 18th-century prose. The ballerina studied only classical styles of dance. The Cubist style of painting was rather controversial when it first appeared. The public library was built in the style of Greek Revival.

sense.name: a type or class of merchandise, product line
sense.commentary: STYLE[+entity][+artifact][+model][+distinctive] Note: refers to different models, types of a class of merchandise
sense.examples: This store has hundreds of styles of tile, including granite and marble. Last year's styles of automobiles are now on sale. Sally was looking for a style of toaster that accommodates extra-thick slices of bread. The magazine shows all the new styles from Paris and Milan. (merchandise itself)

sense.name: a fashion preference in society
sense.commentary: STYLE[+state][+social][+preference][+fashion] Note: refers to a state of preference, not the artifact itself Note: often in the phrases, 'in style' , 'out of style'
sense.examples: Tall boots are very much in style this year. A morning coat and breeches have been out of style for a long time. She never follows the styles of the times. (her preferences are different)

sense.name: elongated portion of a plant pistil
sense.examples: The style of the flower is located between the ovary and the stigma of the pistil.

sense.name: editorial guidelines for grammar and punctuation
sense.examples: The journal has a specific style in which all papers must be submitted. These young writers have yet to master the basic elements of style, such as the correct use of semicolons, and proper use of reflexive pronouns.

sense.name: having the quality of flair or panache
sense.commentary: STYLE[+quality][+appearance][+flair] Note: always implies a positive trait of personal elegance or splendor
sense.examples: She entertains with great style, whether it's a small dinner party or a gala affair. The students loved the dash and personal style of the young professor. The hostess handled the awkward situation with great style. They lived in high style in New York during the 1920s.

sense.name: a pointed instrument for writing, stylus
sense.examples: He drew the design on the stencil with a steel style.

sense.name: a tubular appendage or outgrowth of animals, e.g., fish
sense.examples: The diagram in the biology book illustrates a cartilaginous style on the tongue of a fish.

sense.name: a legal title, official name
sense.examples: The partnership traded under the style of Starr and Mortimer.

sense.name: the gnomon of a sundial
sense.examples: The shadow of the sundial's style pointed at 3 o'clock.

sense.name: the needle of a phonograph
sense.examples: John bought a new style for his phonograph so he could listen to old LPs. The rapper rubbed a style across the vinyl record to produce a rhythmic sound.
